newsitem.title: MEXICO: Pemex concerned about delay in petrochemical sale.
newsitem.headline: Pemex concerned about delay in petrochemical sale.

text.p: Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) head Adrian Lajous on Wednesday warned that public and private investment in the petrochemical industry has been hit by the delay in privatizing secondary petrochemical plants.
"It worries me that the delay in this process has affected the levels of investment in petrochemicals," Lajous told a news conference.

He echoed views aired Tuesday by U.S. Ambassador to Mexico James Jones that potential foreign investors could take their funds to other Latin American countries where privatizations in the energy sector have made greater headway.

Some 18 months after the Mexican government announced its decision to sell off its secondary petrochemical plants, Lajous said Pemex -- the state-owned oil monopoly -- was still in the dark about details of the process.
"Pemex is awaiting specific and precise directives from the authorities on this matter," he said.

The sale of the first complex, Cosoleacaque, has been delayed since April because of opposition from unions, leftist political parties and, most recently, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.
Public ownership of Mexico's oil industry is considered sacred by many in Mexico since it was seized from foreigners by the government in 1938.
